spanishExample: En verdad, hay una casa ahí *where* fuimos.
englishTranslation: Actually, there is a house there where we went.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: ¡Ya está! Siempre *I do* mi *homework.*
englishTranslation: All done! I always do my homework.
vocabIncluded: ya está: idiom meaning "it's done", "all done", etc.

spanishExample: ¿Fuiste? *I think* que ella había ido *too.*
englishTranslation: Did you go? I think she had gone too.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
había: "had", "he/she/it had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡Buenas tardes! ¿Ese *phone* es tu *phone?*
englishTranslation: Good afternoon! Is that phone(m) your phone?

spanishExample: ¡Buen día! Estaré *happy* al *eating lunch,* ya que *I’m hungry.*
englishTranslation: Good day! I’ll be happy upon eating lunch, since I’m hungry.
vocabIncluded: estaré: "will be", "I will be" (Estar, future, 1st person)
ya que: idiom meaning "since" in a logical sense

spanishExample: ¡Buenas noches! ¡*I hope* que vaya a *the party* ese día!
englishTranslation: Good evening! I hope you(formal) go to the party that day!
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: ¡Hola, buenos días! Por favor *come* conmigo.
englishTranslation: Hi, good morning! Please come with me.

spanishExample: Nunca he estado ahí y solo *I want* ir.
englishTranslation: I have never been there and I only want to go.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: *I hope* que seamos *better people* al estar con ellos.
englishTranslation: I hope we are better people upon being with them.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: *I think* que no iba a ir.
englishTranslation: I think she wasn’t going to go.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
iba: "was going", "he/she/it was going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Lo *I want* hacer este año por si voy a Argentina.
englishTranslation: I want to do it this year in case I’m going to Argentina.

spanishExample: Le *I’ll give* esto si *he comes* esta tarde.
englishTranslation: I’ll give him this if he comes this afternoon.
vocabIncluded: le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Me estoy *looking* y nadie es tan *tall.*
englishTranslation: I’m looking at myself and nobody is so tall.
vocabIncluded: tan: "so" as an adverb right before an adjective or adverb

spanishExample: Si te *you look* en *the mirror,* nosotros nos *will look.*
englishTranslation: If you look at yourself in the mirror, we will look at ourselves.

spanishExample: De verdad, estarían ahí si la *they saw.*
englishTranslation: Really, they would be there if they saw her.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
estarían: "would be", "they would be" (Estar, conditional, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Está por *to finish, so* habrá *finished* para esta noche.
englishTranslation: She is about to finish, so she’ll have finished by tonight.
vocabIncluded: "para": "by" a moment in time, as in "by then"
habrá: "will have", "he/she/it will have" before a participle (Haber, future, 3rd person)
the use of "por" after Estar to mean "about to"

spanishExample: Están *happy* cuando me *they see.*
englishTranslation: They are happy when they see me.

spanishExample: Somos lo que *we want* ser.
englishTranslation: We are what we want to be.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: ¿Qué *do you think* que habrá con él?
englishTranslation: What do you think that there will be with him?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
habrá: "there will be" indicating existence (Haber, future, impersonal)

spanishExample: No nos habías *seen.*
englishTranslation: You hadn’t seen us.
vocabIncluded: habías: "had", "you had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Ibas a ir *to see the movie* por *the Mexican director.*
englishTranslation: You were going to go to see to the movie by the Mexican director.
vocabIncluded: ibas: "were going", "you were going" (Ir, imperfect, 2nd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: ¡De nada! ¿Tú lo *want* hacer ahora?
englishTranslation: You’re welcome! Do you want to do it now?

spanishExample: Tus amigos no nos *told* la verdad.
englishTranslation: Your friends didn’t tell us the truth.
vocabIncluded: nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: Ya está, ella ya se va.
englishTranslation: All done, now she is leaving.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
ya está: idiom meaning "it's done", "all done", etc.
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: ¿Han estado ahí?
englishTranslation: Have they been there?
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
han: "have", "they have" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: ¡Hola! ¿Todo bien en la casa?
englishTranslation: Hi! All good in the house?

spanishExample: ¿Cómo estaba ese día? ¿Todo bien?
englishTranslation: How was he that day? All good?
vocabIncluded: cómo: adverb meaning "how?" in a question or implied question

spanishExample: ¡Yo lo he hecho mejor!
englishTranslation: I have done it better!
vocabIncluded: he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: No iré a esa casa, pero iré a esta.
englishTranslation: I won’t go to that house, but I’ll go to this one.
vocabIncluded: iré: "will go", "I will go" (Ir, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Hay una casa donde estabas?
englishTranslation: Is there a house where you were?
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: Mi amiga es más *intelligent* que él.
englishTranslation: My friend(f) is more intelligent than him.

spanishExample: Ella es buena y por eso ha ido ahí.
englishTranslation: She is nice and that’s why she has gone there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Ella estaba ahí por él.
englishTranslation: She was there on behalf of him.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener

spanishExample: Ella estará ahí cuando vayamos.
englishTranslation: She will be there when we go.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
estará: "will be", "he/she/it will be" (Estar, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡Gracias por hacer eso!
englishTranslation: Thank you for doing that!

spanishExample: El señor *has* una buena vida.
englishTranslation: The gentleman has a nice life.

spanishExample: La señora va a ir con sus amigos.
englishTranslation: The lady is going to go with her friends.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: El hombre va por su amigo.
englishTranslation: The man is going on behalf of his friend.

spanishExample: La verdad es que son así.
englishTranslation: The truth is that they are that way.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"

spanishExample: Las mujeres *have* muchas cosas.
englishTranslation: The women have a lot of things.

spanishExample: La señorita estuvo aquí por el día, pero no por la noche.
englishTranslation: The young lady was here during the day, but not during the night.

spanishExample: Va a haber alguien porque ella fue ahí.
englishTranslation: There is going to be someone because she went there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
haber: "there to be" indicating existence (Haber, infinitive)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Había alguien más con ustedes.
englishTranslation: There was someone else with you all.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
había: "there was/were" indicating existence (Haber, imperfect, impersonal)
ustedes: plural "you" after a preposition (prep. pronoun)

spanishExample: Esta vez mi amigo y yo estaremos ahí.
englishTranslation: This time my friend(m) and I will be there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
estaremos: "will be", "we will be" (Estar, future, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Nosotras no lo estamos haciendo, ya que no estamos bien.
englishTranslation: We(f) aren’t doing it, since we’re not well.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
ya que: idiom meaning "since" in a logical sense

spanishExample: Sí, ella estaba aquí, pero ¿por qué tú estabas aquí?
englishTranslation: Yes, SHE was here, but why were YOU here?

spanishExample: Ustedes se fueron con una mujer.
englishTranslation: You all left with a woman.
vocabIncluded: irse: any use of Ir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "leave"
ustedes: "you" plural, subject pronoun (3rd-person plural treatment)

spanishExample: Usted estaba haciendo lo que ellos ya habían hecho.
englishTranslation: You(formal) were doing what they had already done.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
habían: "had", "they had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person plural)
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things
